entry.title: Sailing Analytics Goes Open Source
entry.content:
On October 20, 2025, SAP published the source code of the Sailing Analytics solution and its companion apps (Sailing Race Manager, Buoy Pinger, Sail Insight) on GitHub under the Apache 2.0 license. This finally allows all interested parties to contribute to the solution, and optionally even host it themselves. 

This was a logical next step for the project and remains in-line with SAP’s open source principles described in the SAP Open Source Manifesto. It lays out a vision where open source drives innovation through collaboration and empowers communities through openness. 

What Sailing Analytics Does 

The Sailing Analytics solution helps comment and analyze sailing regattas by combining data from satellite tracking, wind sensors, and decisions by the race committee into live results and analyses. As a cloud solution, it scales from small cost-efficient club-level events to the most visible regattas at the Olympic Summer Games in Tokyo (2020/2021) and Paris (2024), serving hundreds of thousands of concurrent viewers across several regions worldwide. It powers the world's largest sailing tracking database with wind data and proper score boards (https://sapsailing.com). See it in action, live from the upcoming Youth World Championships 2025 in Vilamoura, Portugal taking place December 12-20, 2025, at https://youthworlds2025.sapsailing.com. 

While Sailing Analytics started in the domain of one-design dinghy sailing with a specific focus on Olympic classes, over time it has evolved into many other areas of the complex sport. This includes different handicap formats with support for handicap-based live rankings, and a variety of scoring systems.

 

The solution can be configured to work with different systems for position tracking, wind sensors, external regatta management tools, and official scoring systems. Through its RESTful API it is possible to integrate more external tools and components without a need to change the sources. For tighter integrations, such as tracking systems and administration interfaces, a connector architecture exists that allows developers to extend the solution accordingly.  

Collaboration Models 

With the code base now being released under a permissive open-source license, several new collaboration opportunities have opened.  

In particular: 

  • Sensor technology providers can implement connectivity 
  • Federations, class associations and event hosts can work on new formats and scoring options to be supported 
  • Research institutions can extend the solution for their specific projects and in-depth analysis 
  • Sailing enthusiasts with a background in IT or graphic design can contribute to all layers and aspects of the solution 

Find a Neutral Entity as the New Home 

In the long run, we plan to move this project to a neutral entity, such as a foundation, to collaborate with more individuals and teams to ensure neutral governance. In a foundation, this solution will benefit from established processes for running open-source projects and structures for collaboration that allow interested stakeholders to easily shape the project’s future together.

 

Join Us for a Technical Webinar 

We plan a one-hour webcast on this subject for the beginning of 2026. There you will learn about the status of the project, the potential going forward, and the concrete ways for you to participate, contribute, and collaborate. Let us know if you are interested either in the comments or by using the email below. Please find more details here. 

For those who can’t wait, please also use the project’s discussion board or send an e-mail to support@sapsailing.com to learn more.

entry.title: Re: #COE#RFL01- How to neutralize free Payment
entry.content:
Hello @BobShen

We have found a solution.
I am posting the answer here in case it may be useful to other consultants.

SAP confirms that there is no way to add conditions to free payment.
Also, It is not possible to control the app catalogue by payment method.

We therefore tested a BADI " FINS_ PAYT_REQUEST_VALIDATION" and it seems to meet the requirement.

We still need to check, it does not have any side effects on other payment types.

Hope this will help in the future. 

Best regards, 

Mouna

entry.title: How to connect with SAP S/4HANA OData Services from SAP APIM? - OAuth 2.0 Based Authentication
entry.content:
Assuming that you have enabled the API Management capability in Integration Suite, I will start with API Provider creation.

1. Create API Proxy - To Generate OAuth Authentication Token

Create an API Proxy with URL type, 

2. Add Policy - To generate OAuth 2.0 Authentication

OAuth v2.0 - To generate the Access Token for the ac

<OAuthV2 async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
   <ExternalAuthorization>false</ExternalAuthorization>
   <Operation>GenerateAccessToken</Operation>
   <GenerateResponse enabled="true"/>
       <SupportedGrantTypes>
           <GrantType>client_credentials</GrantType>
       </SupportedGrantTypes>
   <Tokens/>
</OAuthV2>

 

3. Create API Provider

Connection

TypeOn Premise
HostVirtual Host, as mentioned in Cloud Connector
PortVirtual Port, as mentioned in Cloud Connector
Location IDAs mentioned in Cloud Connector
AuthenticationNONE
Additional Properties:sap-client: XXX

Catalog Service Settings

Path Prefix/sap/opu/odata
Service Collection URL
/IWFND/CATALOGSERVICE;v=2/ServiceCollection
Authentication type
BASIC
Username
SAP's User Name for communication
Password
***

Test connection:

4. Create Key Value Map to store the credentials to S/4HANA

5. Create API Proxy - To call the OData Service from S/4HANA

Select the API Provider, click on Discover to select the API which you wanted to use

Select the API & then click on Create.

 

6. Add Policies to the API Proxy created to call the OData target endpoint on S/4HANA side

Verify API Key - To verify the key which you are going to pass while calling the API.
Where do you get the API? - When you create the Product, and a Subscription, after creating a Subscription in the Developer Hub you will get a Key. That key is to be provided to the Consumer, and this Policy will verify the key sent by the consumer.

 

 <!--Specify in the APIKey element where to look for the variable containing the api key--> 
<VerifyAPIKey async='true' continueOnError='false' enabled='true' 
xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<APIKey ref='request.header.apikey '/>
</VerifyAPIKey>

 

OAuth 2.0 - To verify OAuth Token generated

<OAuthV2 async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
   <ExternalAuthorization>false</ExternalAuthorization>
   <!-- valid values are GenerateAccessToken, GenerateAccessTokenImplicitGrant, GenerateAuthorizationCode ,
    RefreshAccessToken , VerifyAccessToken , InvalidateToken , ValidateToken  -->
   <Operation>VerifyAccessToken</Operation>
   <GenerateResponse enabled="true"/><SupportedGrantTypes/>
   <Tokens/>
</OAuthV2>

 

Assign Message - Before setting up basic authentication in a later step, we need to remove the existing Authorization header. I've used the Assign Message policy to achieve this with the following configuration:

<!-- This policy can be used to create or modify the standard HTTP request and response messages -->
<AssignMessage async="false" continueOnError="true" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
    <Remove>   
     	<Headers>      
			<Header name="Authorization"></Header>   
          </Headers>
     </Remove> 
	<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>true</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<AssignTo createNew="false" type="request"></AssignTo>
</AssignMessage>

Key Value Map Operations - To fetch the credentials saved in the Key Value Mapping

<KeyValueMapOperations mapIdentifier="SAP_S4HANA_Credentials" async="true" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
    <Get assignTo="private.usernameFromKVM" index="1">
        <Key>
            <Parameter>Username</Parameter>
        </Key>
    </Get>
    <Get assignTo="private.passwordFromKVM" index="1">
        <Key>
            <Parameter>Password</Parameter>
        </Key>
    </Get>
    <Scope>environment</Scope>
</KeyValueMapOperations>

 

Basic Authentication - To pass the credentials fetched in the previous step.

<BasicAuthentication async='true' continueOnError='false' enabled='true' xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<Operation>Encode</Operation>
	<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>false</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<User ref='private.usernameFromKVM'></User>
	<Password ref='private.passwordFromKVM'></Password>
 	<AssignTo>request.header.Authorization</AssignTo>
</BasicAuthentication>

 

Assign Message - So you get an error as, "{"fault":{"faultstring":"Unsupported Encoding \"br\"","detail":{"errorcode":"protocol.http.UnsupportedEncoding"}}}". 
BR is a data format Brotli which is often defined by backend for webpage loading and not accepted by default. And this Assign Message will help your message reach the target.

 

<!-- This policy can be used to create or modify the standard HTTP request and response messages -->
<AssignMessage async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
 
	<!-- Sets a new value to the existing parameter -->
	<Set>
		<Headers>
		     <Header name="Accept-Encoding">gzip,deflate</Header>
	     </Headers> 
	</Set>
	<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>false</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<AssignTo createNew="false" type="request"></AssignTo>
</AssignMessage>

 

7. Create Product & Add the both the API Proxies

 

8. Create a Subscription for the Product created

7. It's time to test!

entry.title: Re: Title:"Document Identification When Combining Multipl...
entry.content:
Dear @byd,

Below I described my experience in building the reports.

Point 1.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, each business object has its natural key in the VDM CDS views. For example:

Area

Object

Minimal header key in CDS

At item level

Sales (SD)

Sales document

SalesDocument

SalesDocument + SalesDocumentItem

Sales (SD)

Billing document (invoice etc.)

BillingDocument

BillingDocument + BillingDocumentItem

Procurement (MM)

Purchase order

PurchaseOrder

PurchaseOrder + PurchaseOrderItem

Inventory (MM)

Material document

MaterialDocumentYear + MaterialDocument

+ MaterialDocumentItem

Finance (FI)

Journal entry / accounting document

CompanyCode + FiscalYear + AccountingDocument I_JournalEntry / I_JournalEntryItem

+ AccountingDocumentItem

So:

  • In SD/MM, the document number (SalesDocument, BillingDocument, PurchaseOrder) is unique in the system for that object type and is enough as a technical key.
  • In FI, we always need:
    • CompanyCode
    • FiscalYear
    • AccountingDocument

because the accounting document number alone is not globally unique.

If you build one combined data model where you mix SD/MM/FI documents, it is good practice to add a field that identifies the object type:

SourceObjectType (for example: 'SD_SO', 'SD_BIL', 'MM_PO', 'FI_JE')

SourceDocNumber (SalesDocument / BillingDocument / PurchaseOrder / AccountingDocument)

Point 2.

SD / MM

  • For sales documents (I_SalesDocument):
    • Technically, SalesDocument alone is sufficient as the key.
    • SalesDocumentType is very useful as a reporting dimension, but is not required for uniqueness.
  • For purchase orders (I_PurchaseOrder):
    • PurchaseOrder is sufficient as the key.
    • PurchasingDocumentCategory / PurchasingDocumentType are descriptive/reporting fields.

FI

  • For journal entries (I_JournalEntry, I_JournalEntryItem):
    • AccountingDocument + DocumentType is not sufficient.
    • The minimal robust key is:
  • CompanyCode + FiscalYear + AccountingDocument
    • JournalEntryType / DocumentType again should be treated as reporting dimensions, not part of the technical key.

Conclusion for the design document:

  • For SD/MM should to use:
    • SalesDocument / BillingDocument / PurchaseOrder (+ item number for item-level reporting).
  • For FI we use:
    • CompanyCode + FiscalYear + AccountingDocument (+ item number for item-level reporting).

Point 3.

The recommended approach in S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition (especially when using the Custom CDS Views app) is:

3.1 Pattern: use the universal journal as a “hub”

  1. Primary Data Source (Cube) in Custom CDS Views:
    • I_JournalEntryItem
      or
    • a GL line item view (I_GLAccountLineItem) depending on your exact requirements.

These views typically provide:

    • CompanyCode, FiscalYear, AccountingDocument, AccountingDocumentItem
    • Logistic reference fields such as:
      • SalesDocument, SalesDocumentItem
      • BillingDocument, BillingDocumentItem
      • PurchaseOrder, PurchaseOrderItem
  1. Associations to Custom CDS View:
    • Associated Data Source: I_SalesDocument / I_SalesDocumentItem
    • Logical join condition:
    • Sales – sales documents:
  • I_SalesDocument.SalesDocument = I_JournalEntryItem.SalesDocument
    • Sales – billing documents (invoices):
      • Associated Data Source: I_BillingDocument / I_BillingDocumentItem
      • Example join:
  • I_BillingDocument.BillingDocument = I_JournalEntryItem.BillingDocument (+ possibly CompanyCode if available on both sides)
    • Procurement – purchase orders:
      • Associated Data Source: I_PurchaseOrder / I_PurchaseOrderItem
      • Join:
  • I_PurchaseOrder.PurchaseOrder = I_JournalEntryItem.PurchaseOrder
  1. On top of this Custom CDS View (type Cube) you create a Custom Analytical Query, where you:
    • SD/MM/FI keys (SalesDocument, BillingDocument, PurchaseOrder, CompanyCode, FiscalYear, AccountingDocument)
    • Your additional fields: SourceObjectType, GlobalDocumentID
    • Organizational dimensions (Sales Organization, Purchasing Organization, Company Code, etc.)
    • Amounts, quantities, margins, etc. from the journal entry items.
    • Expose as dimensions:
    • Expose as measures:

This is the typical “cloud-native” pattern: instead of joining existing reports, you join released VDM/CDS views using their technical keys.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/8573b810511948c8a99c0672abc159aa.html?profile=20496348

 

3.2 Join two separate report

  • one report output based on SD (e.g. I_BillingDocumentItem),
  • another report output based on FI (e.g. I_JournalEntryItem),

then you should use the following keys:

  • Billing <-> FI:
    • CompanyCode
    • FiscalYear
    • AccountingDocument
    • CompanyCode
    • FiscalYear
    • AccountingDocument
    • SD billing side (billing CDS view):
    • FI side (journal entry CDS view):
    • Join on these three fields.
  • Sales order <-> FI:
    • Either via the chain:
      SalesDocument → BillingDocument → (CompanyCode, FiscalYear, AccountingDocument)
    • Or directly if SalesDocument is available in the journal entry item view in your release.
  • Purchase order ↔ FI:
    • Use PurchaseOrder (and optionally PurchaseOrderItem) on both sides.

Point 4.

4.1 Standard Fiori apps

  • A standard Fiori app may not display all technical key fields on the UI.
  • This does not mean the fields do not exist – they are usually present in the underlying VDM/ CDS view.
  • When building your own reporting, you work with the released CDS views, not with what is visible on a particular Fiori UI.

4.2 Custom CDS Views – what can limit you

  • You can only use released CDS views
  • Not all internal technical fields are exposed.
  • Frequently, logistic reference keys are available only at item level (for example SalesDocument at journal entry item level), so:
    • It is often better to build your cube at item level (I_JournalEntryItem, I_BillingDocumentItem, I_PurchaseOrderItem),
    • and then aggregate in the query/analytic layer,
    • instead of trying to do everything purely at header level.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/0bde695751505c08e10000000a441470.html

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F2170')/S35

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Optimizing Business Processes and Enterprise Architecture with the Integrated Toolchain
entry.content:
In today’s fast-moving digital landscape, organizations need more than isolated tools, they need a seamless, connected ecosystem that enables process transparency, architectural coherence, and efficient execution. That’s why the SAP Enterprise Support team is excited to introduce a new e-learning course: Optimizing Business Processes and Enterprise Architecture with the Integrated Toolchain.

This learning experience is part of the Business Transformation Management Value Map and supports your journey with curated knowledge, hands-on guidance, and practical demonstrations that help you get the most value from the SAP Signavio, SAP LeanIX, and SAP Cloud ALM integration.

Why the Integrated Toolchain Matters

SAP’s Integrated Toolchain is a cornerstone of the RISE with SAP Methodology, designed to bring together the strengths of SAP Signavio, SAP LeanIX, and SAP Cloud ALM into one powerful end-to-end ecosystem. By orchestrating these solutions, the toolchain strengthens collaboration between business and IT, speeds up process synchronization, and ensures smoother transitions from planning to execution.

The toolchain connects:

  • SAP Signavio Process Collaboration Hub

  • SAP Signavio Process Intelligence

  • SAP LeanIX

  • SAP Cloud ALM

Together, they create a consistent, scalable approach to business transformation — enabling process improvements that align with strategic goals and deliver measurable results.

A Practical Walkthrough for End Users

The new e-learning course focuses on helping architects, practitioners, and team members who work with the toolchain after it has been configured. It delivers:

  • A clear, practical walkthrough of each tool from an end-user perspective

  • Step-by-step demonstrations showing how the tools connect and interact

  • Guidance on navigating each component efficiently

Whether you’re analyzing business processes, mapping enterprise architecture, or executing transformation tasks, this course helps you understand exactly how to work effectively within the integrated environment.

To access the E-Learning, you must complete a one-time registration in SAP Learning Hub, edition for SAP Enterprise Support, using your S-User ID.
Click here for the step-by-step registration guide

About the author:  

Rachel is a Topic Expert for SAP Enterprise Support value maps, specializing in Business Transformation Management. With 7 years of experience at SAP and a background spanning roles in  Customer Service and Delivery Consulting. Rachel is passionate about helping customers succeed through SAP Enterprise Support offerings. 

💡 Have questions or feedback around this content? Don’t hesitate to comment down below or contact @RachelMcDonagh.

entry.title: Re: Field ID is empty in Tax Category of TaxSubtotal
entry.content:
Hi MNajjar,

you need to maintain the mapping in /AIF/VMAP for respective Namespace and Value Mapping Name table. Each country does have different name convention so you need to find correct one using the country prefix. For example in my case for DE I need to maintain in /EDUBL namespace both DE_TAX_CATEGORY and DE_TAX_EXEMPT_CODE Value Mapping tables for e-Invoicing to work.

Kind regards,

Petr

entry.title: SAP for Me Access and Authorization Issues for Business One Customers
entry.content:
Hello,

We are SAP Business One customers. I want to access SAP for Me (https://me.sap.com) to track software downloads, licenses, maintenance status, and support-related information.

Although I can log in to SAP for Me, I receive authorization errors in several areas. SAP Support has informed me that these issues must be resolved by our partner.

However, our partner has opened a support request with SAP, but despite multiple requests, they have not shared the Case ID. It's been over a week, and there is still no progress. Therefore, we are unable to track the incident and resolve our authorization issues in SAP for Me.

My Questions:

As an SAP Business One customer, do I need my partner's approval to access software downloads and license information in SAP for Me?

Do customers have administrative rights in SAP for Me, or is this entirely under the partner's control?

What is the correct procedure for resolving SAP for Me authorization and company assignment issues in Business One environments?

Any clarification or guidance would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you.

entry.title: The ‘Field is Required’ validation message is not appearing on the Add Notification screen.
entry.content:
I’m working on the Add Notification screen in SAP Asset Manager 2405, and I have made several fields mandatory using the RequiredFields.js rule.

The validation is working correctly — the transaction does not proceed when the field is empty — however, the “Field is Required” message is not displayed on the UI for the following control:

  • FuncLocHierarchyExtensionControl

Other required fields (such as Work Center and Reported By) show the required message correctly, but this extension control does not.

I have verified the following:

  • IsRequired = true is correctly set in the metadata.

  • The control name matches the ID added in RequiredFields.js.

  • The CheckRequiredFields action is triggered during Save.

  • The ValidationRule (NotificationCreateUpdateValidation.js) is executed.

Despite this, only the validation logic works—the required field message does not appear on the UI for this FormCell.Extension control.

 

Could you please help me understand why the “Field is Required” message does not appear for FormCell.Extension (HierarchyExtension) controls and whether there is any additional configuration or workaround required to make this work?

entry.title: Hide dropdown from Value help annotation
entry.content:
Hello all,

I have a Fiori Elements V4 List Report app with a filterbar and a table. Some fields in the filterbar are annotated to display a value help:

myField @(
        Common.ValueList : {
            $Type : 'Common.ValueListType',
            CollectionPath : 'S4ProjectionEntity',
            SearchSupported: false,
            Parameters : [
                {
                    $Type : 'Common.ValueListParameterInOut',
                    LocalDataProperty : ID,
                    ValueListProperty : 'ID',
                }
            ],
        },
        Common.ValueListWithFixedValues : false,
    )

 I have SearchSupported: false because the CollectionPath is a projection entity from S4 and it is V2, so it does not support $search queries.

This is fine, but Fiori Elements creates a dropdown in the input field that does nothing because the Search is disabled:

Is there any way to remove this dropdown but keeping the value help?
Thanks in advance.

entry.title: RAP event - Additional save > Raise Event > INSERT generates shortdump
entry.content:
Whenever the user calls an OData service, I need to save the data to a table and immediately trigger additional actions. In my case, the preparing and printing of a custom form based on the saved data. In the current setup this generates a shortdump.

To get this to work, I'm using the "with additional save" option within the behavior definition. This provides me with the 'save_modified' method to handle my additional save. If I simply perform an INSERT there, the record is inserted into the database without issue.

However, to properly decouple the process, I raise an entity event 'created', which is defined in the behavior definition.

METHOD save_modified.
    data lt_header type table for event zlp_os_i_del_hdr\\Header~created.
    lt_header = corresponding #( create-header ).
    RAISE ENTITY EVENT ZLP_OS_I_DEL_Hdr\\Header~created from lt_header.
ENDMETHOD.

This event is handled by a separate class.

METHODS:
  consume_created FOR ENTITY EVENT created_instances FOR Header~created.

method consume_created.
  " INSERT here results in shortdump

  loop at created_instances into data(ls_created).
    zlp_os_cl_delivery=>print_label( ls_created-HeaderGuid ).
  endloop.
endmethod.

Normally, in this method, the label is prepared and placed in a print queue. That last step is done using a standard SAP class, which eventually performs an INSERT.

cl_print_queue_utils=>create_queue_item_by_data(
  iv_qname            = lv_printer
  iv_print_data       = lv_pdf
  iv_name_of_main_doc = |Label date/time|
  iv_number_of_copies = 1
).

In case I perform my INSERT there, the system dumps. 

Execution takes place in a transactional context: A "PHASE <modify>" call is
active with "ZLP_OS_BROKER_DELIVERY". The current statement "INSERT <dbtab>" is therefore forbidden.

I was under the impression that the additional save would prevent this from happening. But it seems the event creates a new RAP phase, in which I still can't INSERT anything.

Am I going about this the wrong way? Thanks in advance for the help 🙂

---

Apologies for the Label, the 'Labels' box only accepts the proposed 'GenAI Assisted Content' although this has nothing to do with the subject 🤔 won't let me post without labels, so it is what it is.

entry.title: Re: Activity type confirmation in SAP S/4HANA Public Clou...
entry.content:
Hello @Francesco_Spaggiari1 

Thank you for your question.

Please review these references for more details:

Fulfillment by Percentage of Completion, Review Percentage of Completion, Activity Types: Plan Quantities,

Revenue Recognition Methods for Customer Projects

Blog: How integrated Project Cost and Revenue Planning helps to keep your promises to clients

To summarise, the clean-core approach in public cloud, ensures that Customer Projects automatically update planned costs whenever you create actual postings with an activity type that is not in the work package plan. You cannot disable this in public cloud due to its clean-core principle.

Because of this, any actual time posting that introduces a new activity type will cause the system to increase planned cost, even in a fixed price contract. The idea behind it is to maintain plan vs actual consistency for revenue recognition.

The provided recommendation to prevent this from happening is to ensure that all activity types that may be posted are included in the work package plan even if it has 0 quantity. You may consider as an alternative, to post time with the planned activity type and use internal costing adjustments if need be.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAC date filters
entry.content:
A challenge that we're having is that we'd like to simplify how report consumers can apply date filters in our dashboards.  
We are using an SAC analytic model with acquired data. 
 
What we ideally would like to do:
  1. Give the end user the ability to have a date range filter as a Story filter.  
  2. Have that date filter work for metrics (1) that are logical to count over a date range (easy) and (2) other metrics that only expect a single month (and will crash if they don't receive a single month).  The metric that crashes uses the RESTRICT function to calculate a rolling-12 month count in a numeric point widget. 
  3. We'd like to set the default date filter end date to be the last completed refresh date, which we can access in our Modeler data.  The default date filter start date would then be set to [end date - 24 months]. 
We've accomplished some of the above (point 3) with some page-level scripting and page filters but the holy grail here is a Story filter so users wouldn't need to change a page filter on each page. 
 
Does anyone have some creative thoughts on how to do this? 
 
 Thanks!

entry.title: Re: RAP event - Additional save > Raise Event > INSERT ge...
entry.content:
Hi, 

I believe what you might be missing is the cl_abap_tx=>save( ) to tell the runtime that this execution is happening within the SAVE-phase? In case you understand german, this part or maybe the entire webinar might be helpful: https://youtu.be/K8YctiZ0LNI

I didn't do that much with the event-ing yet myself so I might be wrong. 🙂

But it sounds about right, quoting the docs: 

  • The transactional phases are implicitly set when RAP business events are consumed locally. This means that RAP event handler methods are started in the modify phase when called. If you want to implement database modifications in RAP event handler method implementations, you must explicitly activate the save phase to avoid causing errors detected by the controlled SAP LUW.

hth.

~Marco

entry.title: Re: How to find the Class with Material Number (MATNR) or...
entry.content:
How the linkage works would be

Material master (MARA/MARC) A KMAT material is flagged as configurable (MARA-KMAT = 'X'). The material is assigned to a class of type 300 in table KLAH (class header) and KSSK (object–class assignment). → For KMAT, the object number in KSSK is not the material number directly, but the internal object number (OBJEK).

Configuration object (CUOBJ) When you create a sales order with a KMAT, the system generates a configuration instance (CUOBJ in VBAP). This CUOBJ points to the instance in table INOB (object dependencies). INOB links the CUOBJ to the object number (OBJEK) used in classification.

Characteristics values (AUSP) If values are assigned, they are stored in AUSP. But since you said no values are yet assigned, you won’t see entries there.

So the linkage of tables would be

  • From VBAP, take MATNR and CUOBJ.
  • Use INOB with CUOBJ → get OBJEK.
  • Use KSSK with OBJEK and KLART = 300 → get the class assignments.
  • Use KLAH with CLASS and KLART = 300 → get the class header (name, description).
  • If you need characteristics definitions, use CABN (characteristics) and CAWN (characteristic values).

entry.title: Re: Linking Outgoing Check Information to Journal Entry I...
entry.content:
Good day @Oliver231 

Thank you for your question.

Please review these references for more details:

Configuration of Adobe Document Services, Journal Entries, Manage Outgoing Checks

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_COMMERCE_INTEGRATIONS/8ce6157b995e418093b6e5410bcd74b2/5542577fe23f439b8e60d904fa2e1fb0.html?locale=en-US

In public cloud, filling or extending the Journal Entry XML data provider with additional fields such as the check number is not permitted due to the systems clean-core principle. The XML for both Ledger View and Entry View is strictly controlled and cannot be enriched when you use Custom Fields, extensibility or BAdIs. The reason is that the check number is not part of the accounting document itself and thereby not enabling the Journal Entry to display it.

That means, adhering to the clean-core solution of placing the check number into a field that is part of the FI document is the best practice. That will enable the field appear in the Journal Entry PDF. Alternatively, you can print the check directly in the Manage Outgoing Checks or you may consider building a custom BTP-based correspondence if you required additional details.

Below is a step-by-step clean-core approach to take

First step is in the Post Outgoing Payments app, enter vendor, amount, bank data. In the Document Header Text, enter the check number manually.

Second step is to post the check in the Manage Outgoing Checks. Select the check and confirm assignment.

Step 3 is to display the Journal Entry in the Manage Journal Entries App. Open the posted document; you will see the header text with the check number.

Final step is to create correspondence in PDF. Your check number will appear in the header text since it is part of XML.


Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Building a Smart SAP Service Desk Agent with GenKit and SAP-RPT-1
entry.content:
The Problem: In most SAP organizations, helpdesk teams manually categorize incoming tickets—assigning the right SAP module, setting priority levels, and flagging escalations. It's repetitive work that slows down response times.

The Solution: Replace this manual triage with an AI agent.

In this guide, I'll show you how to build an agent using Google GenKit and SAP-RPT-1 that automatically analyzes ticket descriptions and predicts module, priority, and escalation status. We'll explore why a simple LLM prompt isn't enough—and how a tool-based architecture makes this production-ready.

Note: This is a PoC-level implementation. Since most AI + SAP examples focus on CAP integrations, I wanted to explore a different orchestration framework. Let's see what GenKit brings to the table!

Section 1: Your Development Toolkit & Setup

Step 1. Initialize Your Node.js & TypeScript Project

# Create and enter the project directory
mkdir my-genkit-app
cd my-genkit-app

# Initialize a Node.js project
npm init -y

# Set up the source directory and main file
mkdir src
touch src/index.ts

# Install and configure TypeScript
npm install -D typescript tsx
npx tsc --init

Step 2. Install Genkit and Dependencies

# Install Genkit CLI globally
npm install -g genkit-cli

# Install local project dependencies
npm install genkit @genkit-ai/google-genai dotenv

Step 3. Configure Your API Keys

Create .env file in the root directory:

# .env
GEMINI_API_KEY=your-actual-gemini-api-key-here
SAP_RPT_API_KEY=your-actual-rpt-sandbox-api-key-here

Get Your API Keys:

  • Gemini: https://aistudio.google.com/app/apikey
  • SAP-RPT-1: https://rpt.cloud.sap/dashboard

Why GenKit? It is a lightweight, model-agnostic orchestration framework from Google. It's perfect for implementing AI-powered experiences, provides built-in observability, and works across any cloud provider.

A Quick Note on SAP-RPT-1

Before we dive in, I need to give props to whoever at SAP decided to create the RPT-1 sandbox. Seriously—this person deserves a promotion.

Historically, the biggest barrier to experimenting with SAP's AI/ML tools has been access. Everything was locked behind enterprise licenses, complex provisioning, or buried in AI Core documentation. You'd spend more time getting credentials than actually building anything.

SAP-RPT-1 flips this. You can log in to the sandbox with SSO or email, get an API key in 1 minute, and start making predictions. 

What is SAP-RPT-1?

RPT-1 (Relational Pre-Trained Transformer) is SAP's first open-source AI model, specifically designed for tabular data prediction. Unlike general-purpose LLMs that are trained on text, RPT-1 understands structured data—think spreadsheets, database tables, CSV files.

For our use case (ticket classification), this is perfect. We have historical tickets with columns like SAP_MODULE, PRIORITY, DESCRIPTION, and ESCALATION. RPT-1 can look at patterns in this structured data and predict missing values with surprising accuracy.

The model works by:

  1. Taking your historical data as "context rows" (examples)
  2. Taking your new ticket with [PREDICT] placeholders
  3. Using transformer architecture to understand relationships between columns
  4. Returning predictions based on learned patterns

Think of it as a specialized AI that's really good at one thing: understanding how values in one column relate to values in other columns.

Why Use RPT-1 Instead of Just Gemini?

You might wonder: "Why bother with RPT-1 when Gemini can read tables too?" Valid question. Here's why:

  1. Token Efficiency: RPT-1 is designed for this. You're not burning tokens on JSON formatting and structural overhead.
  2. Specialized Training: It's trained on relational data patterns, not just general text.
  3. Consistent Predictions: For tabular data, RPT-1 gives more consistent, pattern-based results than trying to prompt-engineer a general LLM.

In practice, we'll see that Gemini + RPT-1 as a tool beats Gemini-only approaches by a factor of 36x in token efficiency while improving accuracy.

Section 2: The Journey to an Intelligent Agent (in 3 Attempts)

Quick Note on GenKit Flows

Before we start, a quick word on GenKit's core concept: Flows.

A Flow is a structured AI action with defined input/output schemas. You specify what goes in and what should come out, and GenKit handles the rest. This gives you type-safety, built-in UI for testing, and observability out of the box.

Basic structure:

export const myFlow = ai.defineFlow(
  {
    name: 'FlowName',
    inputSchema: z.object({ ... }),
    outputSchema: z.object({ ... }),
  },
  async (input) => {
    // Your logic here
    return output;
  }
);

That's all you need to know for now. Let's build.

Step 4. Attempt 1: The "Naive" LLM-Only Flow

File: src/index.ts

// src/index.ts - Attempt 1: Naive LLM-only approach
import { genkit, z } from 'genkit';
import * as dotenv from 'dotenv';
import { googleAI } from '@genkit-ai/google-genai';

dotenv.config();

const ai = genkit({
  plugins: [googleAI()],
  model: googleAI.model('gemini-2.5-flash', { temperature: 0.8 }),
});

// Input schema
const TicketInputSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string().describe('Ticket description'),
});

// Output schema
const TicketSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string(),
  sapModule: z.enum([
    "FI", "CO", "MM", "SD", "PP", "WM", "EWM", 
    "HCM", "BW", "CRM", "PM", "QM", "BASIS", 
    "SECURITY", "ADMIN"
  ]),
  priority: z.enum(["Critical", "High", "Medium", "Low"]),
  needEscalation: z.boolean(),
});

// Define the AI Flow
export const ticketPredictFlow = ai.defineFlow(
  {
    name: 'TicketPredictFlow',
    inputSchema: TicketInputSchema,
    outputSchema: TicketSchema,
  },
  async (input) => {
    const prompt = `Act as Service Desk expert.
Based on ${input.description} predict output schema fields (SAP Module, Priority).
If we need to act quickly raise escalation flag.`;

    const { output } = await ai.generate({
      prompt,
      output: { schema: TicketSchema },
    });

    if (!output) throw new Error('Failed to predict');
    return output;
  },
);

async function main() {}
main().catch(console.error);

Run it:

genkit start -- npx tsx --watch src/index.ts

GenKit comes with a built-in developer UI where you can test flows, debug tool calls, and trace execution in real-time. Navigate to localhost:4000 in your browser.

Test in Genkit UI:

{"description": "Can't login to the development system"}

Result:

  • Guessed sapModule: "BASIS"
  • Assigned priority: "Critical"

The LLM lacks business context—it doesn't know that "can't login to DEV" is typically Medium priority, not Critical.

Step 5. Attempt 2: The "Token-Hungry" LLM + History Flow

The next logical step was to provide historical context to the LLM. I generated a 1,000-ticket history.json file to include in the prompt.

But here's something that surprised me: JSON is actually not optimal for LLM prompts.

I know, I know—JSON is everywhere, it's the standard for APIs, we use it without thinking. But when you're feeding data into an LLM context window, JSON is incredibly wasteful. All those quotes, brackets, commas, and structural overhead? Those are tokens. And tokens cost money.

Think about it: {"name": "value"} uses way more tokens than just name: value. Multiply that by 1,000 rows of ticket data, and you're burning through your token budget on syntax instead of actual content.

Enter TOON (Token-Oriented Object Notation). It's a format specifically designed for LLM prompts—strips away JSON's bloat while keeping data readable. The savings? 30-60% fewer tokens for the same data.

For our use case where we're feeding 1,000 historical tickets on every request, this actually matters.

First, install TOON for token optimization:

npm install @toon-format/toon

Create a sample src/history.json file:

[
  {
    "TICKET_ID": "TKT_001",
    "SAP_MODULE": "BASIS",
    "PRIORITY": "Medium",
    "DESCRIPTION": "Cannot login to development system",
    "ESCALATION": false
  },
  {
    "TICKET_ID": "TKT_002",
    "SAP_MODULE": "FI",
    "PRIORITY": "Critical",
    "DESCRIPTION": "Payment posting failed in production",
    "ESCALATION": true
  },
  {
    "TICKET_ID": "TKT_003",
    "SAP_MODULE": "MM",
    "PRIORITY": "Low",
    "DESCRIPTION": "Purchase order print layout issue",
    "ESCALATION": false
  }
]

File: src/index.ts (Updated)

// src/index.ts - Attempt 2: LLM + Historical Context (inefficient)
import { genkit, z } from 'genkit';
import * as dotenv from 'dotenv';
import { googleAI } from '@genkit-ai/google-genai';
import { encode } from '@toon-format/toon';
import historicalDataJson from './history.json' with { type: 'json' };

dotenv.config();

const ai = genkit({
  plugins: [googleAI()],
  model: googleAI.model('gemini-2.5-flash', { temperature: 0.8 }),
});

// Convert historical data to TOON format (saves 30-60% tokens)
const historicalDataToon = encode(historicalDataJson);

const TicketInputSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string().describe('Ticket description'),
});

const TicketSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string(),
  sapModule: z.enum([
    "FI", "CO", "MM", "SD", "PP", "WM", "EWM", 
    "HCM", "BW", "CRM", "PM", "QM", "BASIS", 
    "SECURITY", "ADMIN"
  ]),
  priority: z.enum(["Critical", "High", "Medium", "Low"]),
  needEscalation: z.boolean(),
});

export const ticketPredictFlowWithHistory = ai.defineFlow(
  {
    name: 'TicketPredictFlowWithHistory',
    inputSchema: TicketInputSchema,
    outputSchema: TicketSchema,
  },
  async (input) => {
    const prompt = `Act as Service Desk expert.
    
Historical ticket data (TOON format):
${historicalDataToon}

Based on the historical patterns above and this new ticket description: "${input.description}"
Predict the SAP Module, Priority, and whether escalation is needed.`;

    const { output } = await ai.generate({
      prompt,
      output: { schema: TicketSchema },
    });

    if (!output) throw new Error('Failed to predict');
    return output;
  },
);

async function main() {}
main().catch(console.error);

Result:

⏱️  Time: 12.72 seconds
🪙 Tokens: 22,993 input tokens

Even with TOON optimization, this approach proved to be highly inefficient. Feeding 1,000 tickets to the LLM on every request is fundamentally the wrong architecture—no amount of token optimization can fix that. It's slow, expensive, and doesn't scale.

Section 3: The "Right Way" — LLM as Orchestrator, SAP-RPT-1 as Tool

After the token disaster in Attempt 2, I had to rethink the architecture. The problem wasn't the prompt—it was the fundamental approach.

The Key Insight: Separation of Concerns

Instead of making the LLM do everything (understanding context + making predictions), what if we split responsibilities?

  • Gemini (LLM): Acts as the orchestrator—understands the user's request, decides what needs to happen, formats the final response
  • SAP-RPT-1: Acts as the specialist tool—handles the actual prediction based on historical patterns

This is analogous to how you'd structure a real team. You don't ask a senior architect to also manually check every ticket priority. The architect decides "we need a priority prediction for this ticket," then delegates to a specialist who has the historical knowledge.

How SAP-RPT-1 API Actually Works

RPT-1 is designed specifically for this pattern. Here's the mental model:

You send a POST request to https://rpt.cloud.sap/api/predict with a body containing:

  1. Context Rows: Your complete historical data (all 1,000 tickets with known values)
  2. Query Row: Your new ticket, but with [PREDICT] placeholders for fields you want the model to fill in

Example query row:

{
  "TICKET_ID": "TKT_NEW",
  "SAP_MODULE": "[PREDICT]",     // ← RPT-1 will predict this
  "PRIORITY": "[PREDICT]",        // ← RPT-1 will predict this
  "DESCRIPTION": "Can't login",   // ← We provide this
  "ESCALATION": "[PREDICT]"       // ← RPT-1 will predict this
}

The model looks at patterns in your context rows and predicts the missing values. It's like asking: "Given all these examples where Description X correlated with Module Y and Priority Z, what should the values be for this new description?"

Why This Architecture Wins

Compare the two approaches:

Attempt 2 (Bad):

User Request → LLM with 1,000 tickets in prompt → Prediction
              ↑
        (22,993 tokens, 12.7s, $$$)

Attempt 3 (Good):

User Request → LLM decides: "I need a prediction"
            → LLM calls RPT-1 tool (sends 1,000 tickets to specialized API)
            → RPT-1 returns prediction
            → LLM formats response
              ↑
        (639 tokens, 9.3s, $)

The historical data never enters the LLM's context window. It goes directly to the specialized prediction model that was built for this exact job.

GenKit's Role: Tools

GenKit makes this pattern easy through its "Tools" concept. A tool is just a function that:

  1. Has a defined input/output schema
  2. Can be called by the LLM during generation
  3. Returns structured data back to the LLM

When you give the LLM access to tools, it automatically decides when to use them based on the prompt. You'll see this in the GenKit UI trace—the LLM literally "thinks": "I need to predict ticket properties, I should call the predictTicket tool."

This is the magic of agentic AI: the LLM becomes a coordinator, not a do-everything oracle.

How to Build the SAP-RPT-1 Tool

Now let's implement this. We'll create a GenKit tool that wraps the RPT-1 API call:

File: src/index.ts (Final Version)

// src/index.ts - Final: LLM Orchestrator + SAP-RPT-1 Tool
import { googleAI } from '@genkit-ai/google-genai';
import { genkit, z } from 'genkit';
import * as dotenv from 'dotenv';

dotenv.config();

const ai = genkit({
  plugins: [googleAI()],
  model: googleAI.model('gemini-2.5-flash', {
    temperature: 0.8,
  }),
});

// ===== SCHEMAS =====
const TicketInputSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string().describe('Ticket description')
});

const TicketSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string(),
  sapModule: z.enum([
    "FI", "CO", "MM", "SD", "PP", "WM", "EWM", 
    "HCM", "BW", "CRM", "PM", "QM", "BASIS", 
    "SECURITY", "ADMIN"
  ]),
  priority: z.enum(["Critical", "High", "Medium", "Low"]),
  needEscalation: z.boolean()
});

// ===== SAP-RPT-1 TOOL =====
export const predictTicketWithSAPRPT1 = ai.defineTool({
  name: 'predictTicket',
  description: 'Predicts SAP service ticket properties using SAP-RPT-1 AI model',
  inputSchema: TicketInputSchema,
  outputSchema: TicketSchema
}, async (input) => {
  try {
    // Load historical data (in production, this could come from a database)
    const historicalDataJson = (await import('./history.json', {
      with: { type: 'json' }
    })).default;

    // Create prediction row with [PREDICT] markers
    const predictionTicket = {
      TICKET_ID: "TKT_PREDICT",
      SAP_MODULE: "[PREDICT]",
      PRIORITY: "[PREDICT]",
      DESCRIPTION: input.description,
      ESCALATION: "[PREDICT]",
    };

    // Build request: historical context + new ticket
    const body = {
      rows: [...historicalDataJson, predictionTicket],
      index_column: "TICKET_ID",
    };

    // Call SAP-RPT-1 API
    const response = await fetch('https://rpt.cloud.sap/api/predict', {
      method: 'POST',
      headers: {
        'Content-Type': 'application/json',
        'Authorization': `Bearer ${process.env.SAP_RPT_API_KEY}`,
      },
      body: JSON.stringify(body)
    });

    if (!response.ok) {
      throw new Error(`SAP-RPT API error: ${response.status} ${response.statusText}`);
    }

    const data = await response.json();
    const prediction = data.prediction.predictions[0];

    // Map RPT-1 response to our schema
    return {
      description: input.description,
      sapModule: prediction.SAP_MODULE[0].prediction,
      priority: prediction.PRIORITY[0].prediction,
      needEscalation: prediction.ESCALATION[0].prediction === "1.0" ? true : false
    };

  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error calling SAP-RPT API:', error);
    throw new Error(`Failed to get prediction from SAP-RPT: ${error instanceof Error ? error.message : 'Unknown error'}`);
  }
});

// ===== MAIN AGENT FLOW =====
export const serviceTicketAgent = ai.defineFlow(
  {
    name: 'ServiceTicketAgent',
    inputSchema: TicketInputSchema,
    outputSchema: TicketSchema,
  },
  async (input) => {
    const prompt = `Act as Service Desk expert. Analyze ticket description: ${input.description}.
    
Predict and return JSON with:
- SAP Module (FI, CO, MM, SD, etc.)
- Priority (Critical, High, Medium, Low)
- requiresEscalation: true if downtime, data loss, security risk, or critical response needed

Use historical patterns for consistent routing decisions.`;

    // Genkit automatically decides when to call the tool
    const { output } = await ai.generate({
      prompt,
      output: { schema: TicketSchema },
      tools: [predictTicketWithSAPRPT1]
    });

    if (!output) throw new Error('Failed to predict');
    return output;
  },
);


async function main() {

}

main().catch(console.error);

Complete File Structure

my-genkit-app/
├── src/
│   ├── index.ts          # Main code
│   └── history.json      # Historical tickets
├── .env                  # API keys (don't commit!)
├── .gitignore           # Add .env here
├── package.json
└── tsconfig.json

Results Comparison

Attempt Time Input Tokens Cost

1: Naive LLM~3s150
2: LLM + History12.7s22,993
3: LLM + RPT-1 Tool9.3s639

Winner: Attempt 3 - 36x more token-efficient than Attempt 2

When This Approach Makes Sense

Use This Architecture When:

  • You have historical tickets for training context
  • Historical data have good quality
  • You need consistent, explainable predictions
  • Token costs matter (high volume environments)

Don't Use This For:

  • One-off tickets without historical patterns
  • Unclear or constantly changing categories
  • Simple keyword-based routing (regex is cheaper!)

Useful Links

  • SAP-RPT-1 Sandbox: https://rpt.cloud.sap/dashboard
  • SAP-RPT-1 GitHub: https://github.com/SAP-samples/sap-rpt-1-oss
  • SAP-RPT-1 Product Page: https://www.sap.com/products/artificial-intelligence/sap-rpt.html
  • GenKit Documentation: https://firebase.google.com/docs/genkit

Found this helpful? Share your thoughts in the comments or connect with me to discuss AI integration.

entry.title: Re: SAPUI5 application in Build Workzone with CAP Applica...

Well i kinda solved the problem by moving the SAPUI5 application to the same repository and structure of the CAP Backend, so this SAPUI5 now looks more like a microfrontend for the CAP application, and from within I can setup the app router to internally forward requests to the CAP backend in xs-app.json, given that the destination in xs-app.json points to a destination that has its URL mapping to the 

~{srv-api/srv-url}, which is the same url of the cap backend. if you check capire samples and pretty much CAP, i'd say 99% of the apps work with this landscape so this might be the way to go.
 
However, I believe that Workzone it should be able to forward requests towards other services by using the managed app Router, but trying to follow the documentation of Build workzone i couldn't make it work.

entry.title: Certified Excellence: How Cognizant Sets the Benchmark for Driving Real SAP Transformation
entry.content:
Our longstanding partner Cognizant sheds light on how it is redefining SAP services for a cloud-first, AI-powered world.

In this interview, Sivakumar Varadananjayan, Assistant Vice President and Delivery Head – SAP Cloud & SAP GGM Product and Resources (Global Growth Market) at Cognizant Technology Solutions, shares insights about Cognizant's Path from ERP to AI-Powered, Industry-Focused Innovation. As the leader of Cognizant’s SAP Certification initiative and its Validation Partner status, Sivakumar also shares his perspective on Cognizant’s renewed global certifications, the evolution of their SAP certification journey, and how they plan to further expand their SAP competencies to support customers. The conversation was conducted during Cognizant’s SAP Certification process, together with Christoph Andre, SAP Auditor and Partner Manager, who led the audit at Cognizant, and Hossam Saad, SAP Partner Manager and Cognizant’s main point of contact.

Sivakumar outlines how they have evolved from traditional ERP implementations to a transformation model centered on automation, intelligence, and industry specificity. He also discusses their role as a RISE with SAP Validated Partner, its commitment to SAP Best Practices, and how cloud migrations are accelerated through clean-core principles and end-to-end governance. With renewed global SAP certifications, expanded security capabilities, and deep DevOps integration, Cognizant positions itself as a pioneer in secure, future-ready SAP transformation. Looking ahead, Sivakumar shares how continued investment in talent, co-innovation, and industry-focused solutions will shape the next chapter of intelligent enterprise modernization.

 

Christoph: Cognizant is globally known for providing SAP-related services. How have you been adapting your services to ever-changing customer needs and technology innovations?

Sivakumar: Adaptability is at the heart of Cognizant’s SAP strategy. Over the past decade, we’ve transitioned from traditional ERP implementations to cloud-first, AI-enabled, and automation-driven models. Our approach focuses on three pillars:

  • Cloud Enablement: We leverage SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) to deliver scalable, resilient architectures that support rapid innovation and business agility.
  • Intelligent Automation: Through SAP Business AI, Joule Agents, and Cognizant’s Automation Fabric, we integrate robotic process automation and generative AI into SAP workflows, reducing manual effort and improving accuracy.
  • Customer-Centric Design: We co-innovate with clients using SAP’s cloud solutions and industry accelerators, ensuring transformation aligns with their business priorities and delivers measurable outcomes.

Innovation is embedded in every stage – from RISE with SAP S/4HANA Conversions to AI-powered solutions like SAP-Certified Case Management AI Agent for SAP and Finance4U® for industry-specific needs. These capabilities enable real-time insights, predictive analytics, and continuous modernization, helping clients thrive in a rapidly changing digital economy.

 

Christoph: Cognizant positions itself as a pioneer in leveraging SAP Business Suite, cloud ERP, and Business AI. How do you tailor your SAP services to address industry-specific challenges, and what role does innovation play?

Sivakumar: Cognizant tailors its SAP services through a deep industry-in-context approach - combining process expertise, data intelligence, and AI-driven automation to address the unique challenges of each sector. Our strategy integrates SAP Business Suite, cloud ERP, and Business AI with domain accelerators, industry templates, and pre-built integration frameworks that shorten time-to-value and enhance business agility.

Innovation is embedded in every stage - from co-innovation with SAP and hyperscale cloud platforms to leveraging SAP Business AI, developing digital twins, and advanced analytics for continuous transformation. This ensures that clients don’t just modernize their ERP landscape but also unlock new business models, improve decision velocity, and stay future-ready in an AI-enabled economy.

A strong example of this innovation-led, industry-tailored approach is reflected in Cognizant’s Utegration portfolio for utilities and energy enterprises:

  • Finance4U® Extended Asset Accounting: Enhances SAP property accounting with regulatory-compliant, utility-specific asset management capabilities.
  • Finance4U® Regulatory Accounting and Reporting: Streamlines regulated financial reporting, improving data accuracy and audit readiness.
  • Utility4U™: A RISE with SAP-based cloud accelerator that modernizes and simplifies the utility ERP landscape while embedding industry best practices.
  • MeterData4U®: Unlocks the value of Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI) by integrating and operationalizing meter data within SAP environments.

Together, these offerings demonstrate how Cognizant combines deep domain experience with SAP innovation to deliver measurable outcomes across industries - from operational efficiency to intelligent, data-driven growth.

 

Hossam: As a “RISE with SAP Validated Partner,” what has been your experience in leading SAP customers’ migration to cloud? How are your services modeled around SAP Best Practices?

Sivakumar: As a RISE with SAP Validated Partner, our experience in leading SAP customers’ migration to the cloud has been extensive and transformative. We have successfully delivered large-scale migrations for global enterprises using SAP’s validated methodology, ensuring predictable timelines, reduced risks, and accelerated time-to-value. Our approach emphasizes clean core principles with embedded quality gates, supported by SAP Cloud ALM for governance and compliance.

Our services are modelled around SAP Best Practices, integrating SAP’s ecosystem tools such as Cloud ALM, LeanIX, Signavio, Business Technology Platform (BTP), Joule, and Tricentis Test Automation. This toolchain enables automation, collaboration, and robust governance throughout the migration journey. Additionally, all key roles - Project Managers, Architects, Developers, and Consultants - are SAP-certified and trained on the latest cloud and AI innovations, ensuring customers are positioned for continuous innovation post-migration.

Finally, we focus on delivering customer-centric outcomes by accelerating cloud transformation with minimal disruption and ensuring smooth migration from ECC or on-premise systems to SAP S/4HANA Cloud. By leveraging SAP Best Practices and validated frameworks, we provide transparent, milestone-driven projects that reduce risk and deliver predictable results. Our engagements consistently achieve high satisfaction scores, reflecting our commitment to quality, innovation, and long-term customer success.

 

Christoph: Cognizant recently renewed global certifications for SAP Business Suite and SAP S/4HANA services and achieved its first global certification for SAP security operations. How do your competencies in DevOps, Security, and Business AI add value?

Sivakumar: Cognizant’s renewed global certifications for SAP Business Suite and SAP S/4HANA services, along with its first global certification for SAP Security Operations, reinforce our ability to deliver secure, agile, and intelligent SAP transformations. These credentials validate our expertise in modernizing SAP landscapes while ensuring compliance and resilience for mission-critical environments.

Our DevOps competency accelerates SAP delivery through automated CI/CD pipelines, enabling rapid release cycles, improved quality, and seamless integration with RISE with SAP and cloud platforms. In parallel, our Security Operations capability provides proactive threat management, robust identity governance, and real-time monitoring - critical for industries with stringent regulatory requirements. Internally, Cognizant leverages a DevOps for a Unified Competency Management model across SAP competencies to bring people, process, and knowledge together around the work we do.

Finally, Business AI brings intelligence into SAP workflows by embedding predictive analytics, generative AI, and automation. This drives faster decision-making, reduces manual effort, and unlocks new business models across sectors. Together, these strengths position Cognizant as a trusted partner for enterprises seeking secure, automated, and AI-powered SAP transformations.

 

Hossam: How has your SAP certification journey evolved - from your first global certification in 2011 to today? What motivated you initially, and how has your approach changed?

Sivakumar: As you have rightly pointed out, Cognizant’s SAP global certification journey began in 2011, when we became one of the earliest partners to achieve SAP Cloud Certification. At that time, our motivation was clear: to build client confidence, demonstrate market leadership, and align with our vision of driving enterprise modernization through cloud-first strategies. This milestone positioned us ahead of industry trends and validated our ability to deliver secure, scalable SAP solutions.

Since then, our approach has evolved from meeting compliance standards to driving continuous innovation. Today, certifications are part of a broader strategy focused on SAP S/4HANA, SAP BTP, and RISE with SAP, integrating AI, automation, and sustainability into transformation programs. We’ve expanded from core ERP to end-to-end digital solutions, strengthened partnerships with SAP and hyperscale cloud providers, and invested heavily in talent development through role-based certifications. For us, certification is no longer a one-time achievement - it’s a continuous journey to deliver measurable business outcomes and stay ahead of client needs.

 

Hossam: Looking ahead, how do you plan to grow your SAP competency and services to support customers?

Sivakumar: Cognizant plans to deepen its SAP competency by focusing on next-generation technologies such as SAP Business AI and industry-specific solutions developed and integrated leveraging SAP BTP. We are investing in advanced capabilities around RISE with SAP, SAP BTP, and SAP S/4HANA transformations, ensuring clients can accelerate their cloud journeys with agility and resilience. Our strategy includes embedding AI-driven automation, predictive analytics, and sustainability frameworks into SAP landscapes, enabling customers to unlock new business models and achieve measurable outcomes. These innovations will be supported by strong partnerships with SAP and hyperscale cloud providers to deliver integrated, multi-cloud architectures tailored to client needs.

 

 

Information on the certification program for operations partners and an overview of all certified partners can be found in the SAP Operations Partner Guide.

Visit OPC at SAP.com or on the SAP Partner Portal.

entry.title: Simplifying AWS EC2 with Cloud Connector installation & SAP DP Agent Integration with BTP
entry.content:
Hi Folks,

This blog demonstrates how to create an AWS EC2 instance, configure storage using LVM, install SAP Cloud Connector and Data Provisioning (DP) Agent, and integrate DP agent with SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) trial account. This setup is ideal for learning and proof-of-concept scenarios.

1.        Overview

We are planning to show you end to end AWS server creation along with mount point creation, and installation of SAP DP & Cloud connector installation, and after that we have configured these systems with BTP free trial account.

Aws trial account -- https://aws.amazon.com/free/

BTP trial account -- SAP BTP Cockpit

2.        AWS EC2 instance creation

As per SAP standard we can only choose SUSE & RHEL image.

Key pair is necessary to generate if you want to access EC2 instance via public ip, other wise server will not authenticate you.

Either you can select existing security group or create new SG

Attach disk as per your requirements

EC2 instance created

To download media and upload into the server we have configure S3 bucket.

3.        S3 bucket Creation

Simply goto S3 and create by selecting create button and enter bucket name and leave all the filled as it is.

4.        Attach IAM role to EC2 instance

To connect S3 bucket with EC2 instance we must attached IAM role to EC2 instance.

Role:

Via Attaching this role we are enabling Connection of S3 bucket with EC2 instance.

5.        Creation of file system

We have used LVM for file system creation, LVM (Logical Volume Manager) is a disk management system in Linux that provides a flexible way to manage storage compared to traditional partitions.

 5.1 validate that separate disk is attach or not via lsblk cmd

PV = Bricks

VG = A big wall built with those bricks

LV = Windows or doors cut out of the wall

5.2   created physical volume pvcreate

5.3 Create Volume group VG
  1. Now we created vg (volume group) from the above pv and validated from vgs command.

5.4 Create LV, Logical Volume
  1. Now we have created lv volume as per our filesystem need
  2. Usrsap - /usr/sap – sap filesystem
  3. Optsapscc - /opt/sap/scc – cloud connector installation

5.5 Disk Formating by mkfs command
  1. Run mkfs command as per below screenshots for all the logical volumes that we need to create

Blkid – to check disk formatting

5.6 Maintain entry in Fstab to get the mount permanent
  1. Now maintain fstab entry as per blkid

5.6 Creation folder creation and mount point creation

                Mkidr -p /foldername

                Mount -a

6.        Cloud Connector installation
           6.1 Download media from S3:

We have already downloaded media and uploaded in S3 that we have created earlier.

           6.2 Installation of jvm

(before installing cloud connector we have to install jvm)

           6.3 Installation of Cloud connector

7.        Installation of DP agent
  1. Creating logical volume and disk formatting

  1. Maintaing in fstab

7.1 Creating filesystem for DP agent

7.2 Copying media from S3 to local mount point

7.3 Creating os user for the installation

7.4 Installing libraries

Once required libraries are installed you can start DP agent installation.

8.        BTP trial account

https://account.hanatrial.ondemand.com/trial/#/home/trial

8.1 Assign role in your BTP user

This is the first thing we have to complete when we are trying to configure CC or DP agent from BTP.

Cloud Connector Admin role for CC configuration with BTP subaccount.

To install SAP hana cloud admin we need SAP HANA Cloud Admin.

8.2 Create hana cloud instance service

Click on the hana cloud

From there you can create an instance

8.3 Enable DP agent & cloud connector

To configure DP agent, you should enable DP agent, you can do this either during the instance creation or you can also enable after instance creation as well by manage configuration.

And all IP addresses for better connectivity

BTP hana instance created

8.4 Create Technical user for DP agent registration

HANA User Name for Agent Messaging - Technical user as per your requirements, refer to SAP help guide for user creation, roles, and privileges.

https://help.sap.com/docs/HANA_SMART_DATA_INTEGRATION/018757bb7f5c4700a8840976c8730f34/1e648c93d82f4...

8.5 Allow all inbound ips from DP agent server.

8.6 DP agent configuration with BTP Hana cloud instance

Purpose of DP agent:

Setting Up and Configuring the Data Provisioning Agent to Connect

Start agent cli tool from DP agent server.

Agent cli tool connected with the HANA cloud instance as per above screenshot, now try to register agent.

Check agent status, if everything is correct you will see green status as per below screenshot.

Check agent info from hana cloud instance as well.

So till this part we have configured DP agent with hana cloud instance, now if you wants to replicate data from backend abap systems then you have to configure by creating remote source, for better understanding check this blog.

Transferring data from On-Premise SAP HANA to SAP ... - SAP Community

9.        Cloud connector configuration with BTP subaccounts.

SAP Cloud Connector is an optional on-premise component that establishes a secure communication link between customer's on-premise network and SAP Business Technology Platform or SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Conclusion

You now have a fully functional setup integrating AWS infrastructure with SAP BTP trial using DP Agent. This foundation enables secure connectivity and data provisioning for SAP HANA Cloud.

entry.title: Re: The Ultimate Guide to Margin Analysis (CO-PA) in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
HI @mickaelquesnot,

thank you for the comprehensive post.

However, I would like to make the remark that your comparison between account-based CO-PA and Margin Analysis at the baseline for this post is incorrect. 

The two options existing for CO-PA in SAP S/4HANA are actually:

  • Margin Analysis (formerly called account-based profitability analysis) and
  • Costing-based profitability analysis (which is the one you are referring to in you post).

Please see some SAP sites for the explanation:

  • https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/5e23dc8fe9be4fd496f8ab556667ea05/87b9bd54c3378e21e10000000a44176d.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST
  • https://learning.sap.com/courses/profitability-analysis-in-sap-s-4hana/costing-based-co-pa-vs-margin-analysis-1

Thank you and kind regards

entry.title: Re: WIP reversal process
entry.content:
Hola, solo pongo lo que hice yo por si a alguien mas le sirve.

Para dar reversa al WIP, solo hay que anular la liquidación, en mi caso use CO88H.

Los pasos que hice para el cierre fueron los siguientes:

1.- KSS2

2.- KSII

3.- KON2

4.- KKAX

5.- CO88H

6.- CKMLCP.

Para la Reversa, anule en el siguiente orden:

1.- Anular CKMLCP (Opción: Contabilizar Cierre).

2.- Anular CO88H (Aquí se anula el WIP).

Espero que esto les sirva a alguien mas.

entry.title: Re: SAP Community Hobbies Serries: Most weekends, I jump out of airplanes with my friends
entry.content:
@smarchesini - in the US, a typical tandem jump might cost around $250.  Once you obtain a license to jump solo and you have purchased your own 'rig', jumps are typically $25-$30 each. 

People can experience vertigo when jumping, but it is uncommon.  It's a widely-held misconception that you experience "zero gravity" while in freefall.  When jumping from a plane, you won't experience less than about a half a gee. The reason is a bit technical, but - basically - your body experiences a rapid horizontal deceleration.  You are no longer being propelled along by the airplane -- and drag dissipates that initial horizontal "toss".  At the same time, you will accelerate downwards but that acceleration is ultimately limited by drag - which increases dramatically as your vertical velocity builds.  This simulatneous deceleration and acceleration net out to about half a gee at the start of the jump. At some point, you reach "terminal velocity" where your drag equals the pull of gravity -- and - voila - you are back to experiencing "one gee" again - even though you are falling at about 120 miles per hour.

I do not bungee jump or BASE jump.  It might seem ironic, but skydiving is a safety oriented sport.  We always carry a second, reserve parachute. We deploy our main parachute with ample time to deal with uncommon situations.  These similar sports offer no such safety margin - so I consider them beyond my personal acceptable risk envelope.
